subject: Re: [junit] Question about test suites
msgSnippet: David Saff wrote: Done. It is now in source forge. Thanks for sending me the reminder! jeff
messageBody:
David Saff wrote:

Done. It is now in source forge. Thanks for sending me the reminder!

jeff
>
>
> Jeff,
>
> I'm really sorry this fell off my radar. Can you log a bug at
> SourceForge, and I'll be more likely to get to it for the next
> release? Thanks,
>
> David Saff
>



> On Fri, Nov 21, 2008 at 12:08 PM, Jeff <jjg@...
> <mailto:jjg%40jqhome.net>> wrote:
> > Sorry for the response lag too...
> >
> > @Inherited almost does it, but you need to make sure the @Retention
> > annotation is set to RUNTIME too or the annotations will simply get
> > discarded. Looking at the current javadoc for Suite.SuiteClasses this
> > is almost there, and all you should need to do is put @Inherited at the
> > beginning. So something like this is in order:
> >
> > @Inherited // <--- add this
> > @Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
> > @Target(ElementType.TYPE)
> > public static @interface Suite.SuiteClasses{ //rock on...
> >
> > Thanks! And when can we expect a release? :o)
> >
> > Jeff
> >
> > David Saff wrote:
> >>
> >> Jeff,
> >>
> >> Got it. So if @RunWith and @... were @Inherited, your
> >> problem would be solved?
> >>
> >
> >>
> >> Sorry for the response lag,
> >>
> >> David Saff
> >>
> >> On Tue, Nov 4, 2008 at 1:20 PM, Jeff <jjg@...
> <mailto:jjg%40jqhome.net>
> >> <mailto:jjg%40jqhome.net>> wrote:
> >> > Hi David!
> >> >
> >> > Here. Let us say that I had test classes, Test0, Test1. Each of these
> >> > requires a backend to be configured. I'd like to do something
> like this:
> >> >
> >> > @RunWith(Suite.class)
> >> > @...({Test0.class, Test1.class})
> >> > public abstract class MySuite{
> >> > abstract public void setBackend(Backend backend);
> >> >
> >> > @BeforeClass
> >> > public static void doSetup() throws Exception{
> >> > //... stuff to get this all pulled together and configure the tests
> >> > }
> >> > }
> >> >
> >> > Then all a tester needs to do is extend the class MySuite,
> implement the
> >> > method and s/he gets to run their backend against my tests.
> >> >
> >> > Complicating factors are that java does not allow for annotations
> to be
> >> > inherited unless the @interface is created with the @Inherited
> >> > annotation, so attempts to do what is above kick back the message
> that
> >> > there are no tests to run or some such. At least this is my
> >> > understanding of java annotations...
> >> >
> >> > The real life example has not just a couple of test classes, but many
> >> > more that very rigorously exercise the backend. The kludge is to have
> >> > the abstract MySuite class and have the annotations cut and
> pasted every
> >> > time. This is bad since it will make maintainability problematic (we
> >> > have lots of different backend configurations people want to test
> >> > against). What's more several people who want to use this really
> don't
> >> > know that much about jUnit and we'd really like it to be the case
> they
> >> > can write a backend then get good feedback on robustness, failure
> modes,
> >> > you name it.
> >> >
> >> > Is this clearer?
> >> >
> >> > Thanks in Advance!
> >> >
> >> > Jeff
> >> >
> >> > David Saff wrote:
> >> >>
> >> >> Jeff,
> >> >>
> >> >> Can you expand on what you mean by "The problem is that making a
> suite
> >> >> using annotations does not really work so well. The annotations are
> >> >> not inherited."? Can you give an example of what you'd like to do?
> >> >> Thanks,
> >> >>
> >> >> David Saff
> >> >>
> >> >
> >> >>
> >> >> On Mon, Nov 3, 2008 at 2:54 PM, Jeff <jjg@...
> <mailto:jjg%40jqhome.net>
> >> <mailto:jjg%40jqhome.net>
> >> >> <mailto:jjg%40jqhome.net>> wrote:
> >> >> > Hi,
> >> >> >
> >> >> > I am new to this group, so if there is a FAQ or thread that
> addresses
> >> >> > this, please direct me appropriately.
> >> >> >
> >> >> > I wrote a comprehensive set of tests in jUnit that run under
> >> Maven. Now,
> >> >> > these run against a single backend and now several developers
> in my
> >> >> > group would like to use these tests against other backends to
> >> test them.
> >> >> > The most natural way to do this is with the test suite
> mechanism in
> >> >> > jUnit. That is to say, make up a suite that requires merely
> that the
> >> >> > backend be set and test away. Or so I thought.
> >> >> >
> >> >> > The different backends are different projects in our group and
> >> live in
> >> >> > different Maven modules.
> >> >> >
> >> >> > The problem is that making a suite using annotations does not
> really
> >> >> > work so well. The annotations are not inherited. The other
> solution
> >> >> > which is to have the developers make their own suites by
> >> annotations is
> >> >> > also very clunky and will probably break at some point.
> >> >> >
> >> >> > So here is my question: Is there any way to make a test suite
> >> that is a
> >> >> > harness and can be reused?
> >> >> >
> >> >> > I assume that jUnit 3.8's method of explicitly creating a suite
> >> is going
> >> >> > to get deprecated soon, right? So that would be a deadend.
> Also, are
> >> >> > their plans to make annotations inheritable at some point in
> >> jUnit? We
> >> >> > could maybe live with cutting and pasting for the short term if
> >> we knew
> >> >> > that this issue would get resolved at some point.
> >> >> >
> >> >> > Thanks!
> >> >> >
> >> >> > Jeff
